originContent: # Triptych - New Attributes for HTML
translatedContent: # Triptych - New Attributes for HTML

originContent: [Triptych](https://alexanderpetros.com/triptych) is a polyfill for three small HTML proposals:
translatedContent: [Triptych](https://alexanderpetros.com/triptych) is a polyfill for three small HTML proposals:

originContent: 1. [Support PUT, PATCH, and DELETE on forms](https://alexanderpetros.com/triptych/form-http-methods) ([WHATWG issue](https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/3577#issuecomment-2294931398))
translatedContent: 1. [Support PUT, PATCH, and DELETE on forms](https://alexanderpetros.com/triptych/form-http-methods) ([WHATWG issue](https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/3577#issuecomment-2294931398))

originContent: 2. [Enable buttons to make HTTP requests without being wrapped in forms](https://alexanderpetros.com/triptych/button-actions)
translatedContent: 2. [Enable buttons to make HTTP requests without being wrapped in forms](https://alexanderpetros.com/triptych/button-actions)

originContent: 3. Enable links, forms, and buttons to target a part of the DOM for replacement
translatedContent: 3. Enable links, forms, and buttons to target a part of the DOM for replacement

originContent: Work on these proposals is in progress: we've put out the first one and the next two are coming soon.
translatedContent: Work on these proposals is in progress: we've put out the first one and the next two are coming soon.

originContent: If you're interested in working on that, reach out to me!
translatedContent: If you're interested in working on that, reach out to me!

originContent: Status updates at: [https://alexanderpetros.com/triptych#status](https://alexanderpetros.com/triptych#status)
translatedContent: Status updates at: [https://alexanderpetros.com/triptych#status](https://alexanderpetros.com/triptych#status)

originContent: ## Examples
translatedContent: ## Examples

originContent: When the link is clicked, replace `<main>` with the result of `GET /home:`
translatedContent: When the link is clicked, replace `<main>` with the result of `GET /home:`

originContent: ```html
translatedContent: ```html

originContent: Home
translatedContent: Home

originContent: <main> <!-- Existing page content --> </main>
translatedContent: <main> <!-- Existing page content --> </main>
When the button is clicked, replace the whole page with the result of `DELETE /users/354`:

originContent: When the button is clicked, replace the whole page with the result of `DELETE /users/354`:
```html
translatedContent: ```html

originContent: <button action="/users/354" method="DELETE"></button>
translatedContent: <button action="/users/354" method="DELETE"></button>
When the button is clicked, replace the button with the result of `DELETE /users/354`

originContent: When the button is clicked, replace the button with the result of `DELETE /users/354`
```html
translatedContent: ```html

originContent: <button action="/users/354" method="DELETE" target="_this"></button>
translatedContent: <button action="/users/354" method="DELETE" target="_this"></button>
When the form is submitted, replace `<div id=user-info>` with the result of `PUT /users/354`

originContent: When the form is submitted, replace `<div id=user-info>` with the result of `PUT /users/354`
```html
translatedContent: ```html

originContent: <form action="/users/354" method="PUT" target="#user-info">
translatedContent: <form action="/users/354" method="PUT" target="#user-info">

originContent: <input type="text" name="name">
translatedContent: <input type="text" name="name">

originContent: <input type="text" name="bio">
translatedContent: <input type="text" name="bio">

originContent: <button>Submit</button>
translatedContent: <button>Submit</button>

originContent: </form>
translatedContent: </form>
## Background and Design Goals

originContent: ## Background and Design Goals

translatedContent: Triptych is a standards-compatible implementation of a featureset that is both core to HTML, and has a lot of recent traction in the library ecosystem: declarative HTTP requests and partial page replacement.

originContent: Triptych is a standards-compatible implementation of a featureset that is both core to HTML, and has a lot of recent traction in the library ecosystem: declarative HTTP requests and partial page replacement.
translatedContent: I outline the rationale for these proposals in [this talk I gave at Big Sky Dev Con 2024](https://unplannedobsolescence.com/blog/life-and-death-of-htmx/).

originContent: I outline the rationale for these proposals in [this talk I gave at Big Sky Dev Con 2024](https://unplannedobsolescence.com/blog/life-and-death-of-htmx/).

translatedContent: HTML has always supported declarative requests.

originContent: HTML has always supported declarative requests.
translatedContent: The hyperlink is fundamental to the grammar of the web, and the `<a>` tag lets developers specify an HTTP request and subsequent page navigation.

originContent: The hyperlink is fundamental to the grammar of the web, and the `<a>` tag lets developers specify an HTTP request and subsequent page navigation.
translatedContent: HTML 2.0 introduced `<form>` elements, which lets developers specify an alternate HTTP Method (`POST`) and take user input either via URL query parameters or request bodies.

originContent: HTML 2.0 introduced `<form>` elements, which lets developers specify an alternate HTTP Method (`POST`) and take user input either via URL query parameters or request bodies.

translatedContent: The existing semantics for declarative HTTP requests have two major missing pieces: they do not support the full set of HTTP Methods (specifically `PUT`, `PATCH`, and `DELETE`), and they only support the relatively strict paradigms of navigation and form submission.

originContent: The existing semantics for declarative HTTP requests have two major missing pieces: they do not support the full set of HTTP Methods (specifically `PUT`, `PATCH`, and `DELETE`), and they only support the relatively strict paradigms of navigation and form submission.

translatedContent: The library ecosystem shows significant demand for these two features, as well as a third: partial replacement of the DOM with the results of that network request.

originContent: The library ecosystem shows significant demand for these two features, as well as a third: partial replacement of the DOM with the results of that network request.
translatedContent: The [buzziest](https://risingstars.js.org/2023/en#section-framework) library that supports these features is [htmx](https://htmx.org/), but it is far from alone.

originContent: The [buzziest](https://risingstars.js.org/2023/en#section-framework) library that supports these features is [htmx](https://htmx.org/), but it is far from alone.
translatedContent: 37Signals (which invented Ruby on Rails) maintains [Hotwired](https://hotwired.dev/), an HTML-over-the-wire framework with an HTML interface, [Turbo](https://turbo.hotwired.dev/), for partial page replacement.

originContent: 37Signals (which invented Ruby on Rails) maintains [Hotwired](https://hotwired.dev/), an HTML-over-the-wire framework with an HTML interface, [Turbo](https://turbo.hotwired.dev/), for partial page replacement.
translatedContent: [Unpoly](https://unpoly.com/) adds attributes that let you target fragments of the page to get replaced, and supports the full range of HTTP methods.

originContent: [Unpoly](https://unpoly.com/) adds attributes that let you target fragments of the page to get replaced, and supports the full range of HTTP methods.

translatedContent: Triptych is an attempt to incorporate in attributed-based DOM replacement into the HTML standard, in

originContent: Triptych is an attempt to incorporate in attributed-based DOM replacement into the HTML standard, in
translatedContent: a manner that best fits existing HTML semantics. It aims to demonstrate the efficacy of these

originContent: a manner that best fits existing HTML semantics. It aims to demonstrate the efficacy of these
translatedContent: proposals, to advocate for their addition to the HTML standard, and to provide that functionality as

originContent: proposals, to advocate for their addition to the HTML standard, and to provide that functionality as
translatedContent: a polyfill until then. Its design is primarily inspired by [htmx](https://htmx.org/) and

originContent: a polyfill until then. Its design is primarily inspired by [htmx](https://htmx.org/) and
translatedContent: [htmz](https://leanrada.com/htmz/).

originContent: [htmz](https://leanrada.com/htmz/).

translatedContent: Because the goal of Triptych is to be incorporated into the HTML standard, it does not use namespaced custom attributes (like `ng-*`, `hx-*`, and so on), but instead uses existing (or plausible) HTML standard attributes in a backwards compatible manner.

originContent: Because the goal of Triptych is to be incorporated into the HTML standard, it does not use namespaced custom attributes (like `ng-*`, `hx-*`, and so on), but instead uses existing (or plausible) HTML standard attributes in a backwards compatible manner.
translatedContent: Much of the script's complexity results from the need to not break existing uses of attributes like `target` or `method`.

originContent: Much of the script's complexity results from the need to not break existing uses of attributes like `target` or `method`.

translatedContent: ## Installation

originContent: ## Installation

translatedContent: There is no CDN yet, but even if I upload it to one, [you probably shouldn't use it](https://blog.wesleyac.com/posts/why-not-javascript-cdn).

originContent: There is no CDN yet, but even if I upload it to one, [you probably shouldn't use it](https://blog.wesleyac.com/posts/why-not-javascript-cdn).

translatedContent: Instead, install it like this:

originContent: Instead, install it like this:

translatedContent: 1. Copy `triptych.js` to a folder in your project, i.e. `/vendor/triptych-0.1.0.js`

originContent: 1. Copy `triptych.js` to a folder in your project, i.e. `/vendor/triptych-0.1.0.js`
translatedContent: 1. Serve it at that URL with a really long cache time (I usually set it to a year)

originContent: 1. Serve it at that URL with a really long cache time (I usually set it to a year)
translatedContent: 1. Include it in your document like this:

originContent: 1. Include it in your document like this:
```html
translatedContent: ```html

originContent: <script src="/vendor/triptych-0.1-0.js"></script>
translatedContent: <script src="/vendor/triptych-0.1-0.js"></script>
Make sure to include the version number in the file name so that if/when you update it, the users who have it cached will download the new version.

originContent: Make sure to include the version number in the file name so that if/when you update it, the users who have it cached will download the new version.

translatedContent: I will upload it to `npm` soon, so you can include it as a dependency and serve it straight from node modules (instead of copying).

originContent: I will upload it to `npm` soon, so you can include it as a dependency and serve it straight from node modules (instead of copying).

translatedContent: ## Limitations

originContent: ## Limitations

translatedContent: Because these features are meant to be incorporated into the standard, they simulate the desired browser behavior, up to the limit of JavaScript's ability.

originContent: Because these features are meant to be incorporated into the standard, they simulate the desired browser behavior, up to the limit of JavaScript's ability.

translatedContent: The main limitation involves full page navigation.

originContent: The main limitation involves full page navigation.
translatedContent: When submitting a POST form, the default behavior is to push that URL onto the URL bar and displays the resulting HTML from the form;

originContent: When submitting a POST form, the default behavior is to push that URL onto the URL bar and displays the resulting HTML from the form;
translatedContent: clicking the refresh button resubmits the POST request—after the user confirms that they intended this.

originContent: clicking the refresh button resubmits the POST request—after the user confirms that they intended this.

translatedContent: When `target`s are not supplied on buttons and forms, Triptych simulates the full-page behavior to the best of its ability.

originContent: When `target`s are not supplied on buttons and forms, Triptych simulates the full-page behavior to the best of its ability.
translatedContent: It replaces the entire document and uses the [history API](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/History) to update the browser URL

originContent: It replaces the entire document and uses the [history API](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/History) to update the browser URL
translatedContent: and history.

originContent: and history.
translatedContent: Clicking "back" should basically work as expected.

originContent: Clicking "back" should basically work as expected.

translatedContent: However, because of (very reasonable) limitations in JavaScript, Triptych cannot alter the behavior of the refresh button to make it resubmit a PUT, as proposed.

originContent: However, because of (very reasonable) limitations in JavaScript, Triptych cannot alter the behavior of the refresh button to make it resubmit a PUT, as proposed.
translatedContent: Nor can it simulate one of the primary benefit of doing a POST-redirect pattern—that it resets the current JS environment.

originContent: Nor can it simulate one of the primary benefit of doing a POST-redirect pattern—that it resets the current JS environment.

translatedContent: Also, for all of these requests, the browser should show a loading bar, the same way that clicking on a link does.

originContent: Also, for all of these requests, the browser should show a loading bar, the same way that clicking on a link does.
translatedContent: This behavior is impossible to simulate in JavaScript but would significantly benefit the user if incorporated into the browser—it's one of the main things lacking from *all* JavaScript frameworks.

originContent: This behavior is impossible to simulate in JavaScript but would significantly benefit the user if incorporated into the browser—it's one of the main things lacking from *all* JavaScript frameworks.

translatedContent: ## Development

originContent: ## Development

translatedContent: The entire source is in `./triptych.js`.

originContent: The entire source is in `./triptych.js`.

translatedContent: To run the tests, first install the dev dependencies with `npm install`.

originContent: To run the tests, first install the dev dependencies with `npm install`.
translatedContent: Then, run the tests by opening `./test/index.html` in your browser.

originContent: Then, run the tests by opening `./test/index.html` in your browser.

translatedContent: You can also play around with manual tests by running `npm run dev`

originContent: You can also play around with manual tests by running `npm run dev`

translatedContent: ### To-do

originContent: ### To-do

translatedContent: * Add full-page tests that verify existing GET/POST forms are not affected

originContent: * Add full-page tests that verify existing GET/POST forms are not affected
translatedContent: * Investigate server-side re-targeting controls (probably headers)

originContent: * Investigate server-side re-targeting controls (probably headers)
translatedContent: * Investigate CSS attributes for in-progress requests

originContent: * Investigate CSS attributes for in-progress requests

translatedContent: ## FAQ

originContent: ## FAQ

translatedContent: ### Should I use this in my project?

originContent: ### Should I use this in my project?

translatedContent: Yes and no.

originContent: Yes and no.

translatedContent: The traditional purpose of a polyfill is to provide functionality to webpages before that functionality becomes standard.

originContent: The traditional purpose of a polyfill is to provide functionality to webpages before that functionality becomes standard.
translatedContent: In the case of Triptych, some of that functionality cannot be simulated in JavaScript (see the Limitations section, above).

originContent: In the case of Triptych, some of that functionality cannot be simulated in JavaScript (see the Limitations section, above).

translatedContent: The purpose of this "polyfill" is to provide a demonstration of how these proposals would transform the capabilities of basic HTML.

originContent: The purpose of this "polyfill" is to provide a demonstration of how these proposals would transform the capabilities of basic HTML.
translatedContent: This library's featureset will track the proposals that it is supporting, which will have to incporate feedback, and thus cannot provide strong backwards compatibility guarantees at the start.

originContent: This library's featureset will track the proposals that it is supporting, which will have to incporate feedback, and thus cannot provide strong backwards compatibility guarantees at the start.
translatedContent: But you should definitely use it to get a sense of what authoring HTML could be like.

originContent: But you should definitely use it to get a sense of what authoring HTML could be like.

translatedContent: ### What if multiple elements match the target?

originContent: ### What if multiple elements match the target?

translatedContent: Targeting is done using the [querySelector API](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/querySelector), which performs a depth-first pre-order traversal of the document's nodes.

originContent: Targeting is done using the [querySelector API](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/querySelector), which performs a depth-first pre-order traversal of the document's nodes.
translatedContent: The target will be the first matching element found, per that algorithm.

originContent: The target will be the first matching element found, per that algorithm.
